We can now use interesting techniques using lasers and adaptive optics to correct the lens shape of ground-based telescopes to compensate for that atmospheric distortion so we can do space telescopes from the ground.

Professional astrophotography with CCDs and " normal" telescopes is hard. But if you have the ability to use a telescope in space, it is actually very easy. You just have to point it somewhere and you get a beautiful image, because there are galaxis everywhere. You just have to take a very long exposure.

Of course, you have to figure out the most efficient way to point the telescope at the spot you want, but the computers can do all the hard stuff.

Wouldn't it be easier just to remove the atmosphere? Ooh, we could do it if we flood the atmosphere with antiprotons, it would annihilate the protons in the nuclei of atoms in the atmosphere, leaving just the neutrons and electrons. The electrons would fly off into space having no positive charge to hold them in place, and the neutrons would beta-decay into protons (which would again get annihilated) and electrons (which would escape).

I can see nothing wrong with this plan: NASA get on it!

PS: Before anyone points out the obvious: yes antielectron-neutrinos are also produced during beta decay, but those will just fly off into infinity anyway, so we don't have to worry about it :D

1:45 The Image with the three galaxies: Is that really one shot or multiple images put together? Two galaxies facing us directly, one maybe in a 45° angle, all a similar apparent size (and thus at a somewhat similar distance I would assume), ...

I was curious whether there are notable advantages from choosing orbit of space observatory as you see fit, for example L2 or heliocentric. I imagine it would allow for easier calculations since you don't have to account for Earths spinning and longer exposure time (thus higher quality images). Or is it completely negligible? I know that most historic space telescopes were in geocentric orbits, however it seems that most of current or future projects are going for Sun-Earth L2 orbit.

Hi Minute Physics
I subscribed to your channel a long while ago, when you still posted very advanced things like quantum mechanics and mathematical paradoxes.
But recently I feel like you are leaning on a more basic side of Physics, which make me slightly disappointed. Your channel has been the most (and possibly only) informative source of theoretical Physics on Youtube, and I'd hate to see that advantage disappears.
So from an average subscriber, I believe I speak for many when I ask (beg? i dont know the appopriate word :)) that you bring back the old level of content. After all, MP should be different from other channels in some ways other than graphics style.

Hey minutephysics! Let me first say I love your channel and you have greatly improved my knowledge in physics! I am in the 10th grade and am currently the president and founder of a new club called FAACA. Which stands for Future Astronomers Astrophysicists and Cosmologists of America. We will use telescopes, equations, and computer programs to interest, inspire, and enlighten kids into the cosmos. I find it funny that when he posts a video about a challenging topic, people say it's too confusing, and when he posts a video about a topic like this, people say it was too simple. This is why he should ignore the comments at this point. Can't please everyone.

As for me: I did know this, but it was a well-made video that was well-worth having out there. Good job. Only thing that might have been nice would be a discussion of adaptive optics.

Actually if it wasn't because our world is a lie to accommodate the cover up of the ET presence (and please spare me your ignorant objection because it violates your child world view) then I would argue that space telescopes are obviously much easier than ground telescopes. A Ritchey Chretien is roughly speaking just two mirrors that can be almost arbitrarily thin and require virtually no structural support, making it quite compatible with transport to space. Indeed you could stack quite a few in typical cargo space, whereas a ground telescope has to be extremely rigid to not deflect under gravity and have adaptive optics and cover structure etc etc.
And indeed, if everybody weren't so mindless, it's more than a little obvious to 3D print an arbitrarily large mirror telescope in space that could resolve wild things. Even directly image earth size extrasolar planets.
